title: 108_s2584
content: The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" introduces a credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities investing in value-added agricultural property. The credit is 50% of the property's basis, with a maximum of $30,000 for eligible persons and allocated pro rata among eligible persons in a farmer-owned entity. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments are the qualified investments made by the eligible person in the entity, minus previous investments taken into account for property already in service. The eligible person's qualified investments in farmer-owned entities for property placed in service are limited to $30,000 per taxable year. Qualified value-added agricultural property is defined as property used to add value to a good. Qualified value-added agricultural property is property used to add value to goods derived from renewable organic matter, with a useful life of 3 years or more, owned and operated by an eligible person or farmer-owned entity. Eligible person refers to an individual meeting certain criteria. The term 'eligible person' refers to an individual who materially participates in an eligible farming business, as determined similarly to section 2032A(e)(6) for corporations, cooperatives, partnerships, estates, or trusts. Eligible farming business involves adding value to goods from renewable organic matter with a useful life of 3 years or more. The term 'farmer-owned entity' refers to a corporation or partnership where eligible persons own majority voting power and stock/profits interest. Eligible farming business must not be a passive activity and involves adding value to goods from renewable organic matter with a useful life of 3 years or more. Persons must own 50% or more of the total voting power and profits interest in a cooperative. Constructive ownership rules apply, with family members defined as spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. The family of an individual includes spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren who reside together or jointly operate farming businesses. Qualified investments refer to cash payments for purchasing equity in a farmer-owned entity. The term 'qualified equity interest' refers to specific types of investments, including stock in a domestic corporation, capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, and patronage interest in a cooperative, acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply. The rules for qualified equity interest acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, are similar to section 1202(c)(3). Special rules apply for married individuals filing separately, basis adjustment for qualified value-added agricultural property, and allocation of credit in estates and trusts. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by the amount of credit allowed and recapture under certain dispositions within a 5-year period. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by the amount of credit allowed and recapture under certain dispositions within a 5-year period. Special rules apply in the event of death, where the period is suspended for 2 years after the eligible person's death. Heirs who are also eligible persons may not be subject to certain transfer rules. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for the transfer of property to heirs. The section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010. The value-added agricultural property investment credit is added as part of the general business credit. The credit can be used against minimum tax. The amendment adds the value-added agricultural property credit to the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. It also limits the carryback of the value-added agricultural property credit under section 39. The amendment limits the carryback of the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 39 of the Code. It also adds the credit to the general business credit under section 38 and allows for a deduction for certain unused business credits under section 196. Additionally, there is a basis adjustment under section 1016. The amendment includes a basis adjustment in section 1016 and adds a new paragraph regarding payments with credits under section 38. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendment adds a new value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code, effective for investments made after December 31, 2004.
